awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--Quantifying the Impact of Radiation Belt Electron Precipitation on Atmospheric Reactive Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) and Ozone (O3)
awd_abstract_narration:
This work will study how certain energetic particles in the magnetosphere affect and change of the composition of the region of the atmosphere closer to the surface of Earth. Improved understanding of how different regions of Earth's atmosphere are linked will enhance our predictive capabilities to protect satellites and other technological assets from the effects of solar and magnetospheric storms. This grant will also develop interdisciplinary collaborations across geoscience (magnetosphere, ionosphere, energetic particles, upper and middle atmosphere).

The research will quantify the contribution of energetic electron precipitation from the Van Allen radiation belts to the production of reactive nitrogen oxides (NOx) in the mesosphere and stratosphere and its resultant impact on ozone (O3). Observations from the FIREBIRD (Focused Investigations of Relativistic Electron Burst Intensity, Range, and Dynamics) satellites and Van Allen Probes will be used to produce the particle spectra and the global maps of electron flux that will be used to drive the WACCM-DART model which implements a new D-region chemical scheme to calculate NOx. By adding this new source, i.e., electron flux from the radiation belts, to the WACCM-DART, the deficits of the NOx in the model simulation are expected to be tackled. Once the model can be validated and favorably compare with observations, the impacts of the radiation belt REP on the NOx in the mesosphere and stratosphere, and the O3 in the stratosphere will be quantified.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative project we quantified the contribution of energetic electron precipitation (EEP) originating from the Van Allen radiation belts to the production of nitric oxides (NOx = NO and NO2) in the stratosphere and mesosphere and its resulting impact on ozone (O3). We utilized observations taken by the NASA Van Allen Probes and NSF Focused Investigations of Relativistic Electron Burst Intensity, Range, and Dynamics (FIREBIRD II) CubeSats to estimate the amount of EPP in the atmosphere and simlated its effects using a global Earth System model that includes atmospheric chemistry. Our study showed significant increases in NOx in the middle atmosphere from EEP. It suggests that the current parameterizations of EEP used in models run for making climate predictions may underestimate the duration of electron precipitation following high-speed solar wind stream storms, as well as the contribution to atmospheric ionization from higher energy electrons producing NOx at lower altitudes.

We developed a novel  way to "tag" the NOx from EPP in our numerical simulations and showed that radiation belt electrons dominate NOx production in the middle atmosphere outside of periods where there are solar proton events. Our simulations show that stratospheric NOx is consistently composed of ~5% from EPP sources in the tropics increasing to ~10% at high-latitudes, and that NOx-driven ozone loss peaks in the middle stratosphere where 2-10% of all ozone losses come from EPP NOx.

We ran our model for 100s of years to look at the climate impact of medium energy electron on climate, with a focus on the winter and spring response at high-latitudes. We found a strengthening of the stratospheric polar vortex in early winter followed by a weakening in later winter. There effects on the winter vortex appear to migrate downwards into the troposphere. In another study we examined how climate change might impact the EEP-NOx on stratospheric O3. In our simulations , future scenarios with increasing greenhouse gases cause changes in the atmospheric circulation that brings more EEP-NOx into the stratosphere. This counteracts part of the recovery of ozone due to reduction in reduction in chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

Our study has led to improved understanding of the impact of solar and magnetospheric variability on the Earth's atmosphere, as well as our understanding of how atmospheric layers in our atmosphere are chemically and dynamically coupled.

Modified by: Daniel R Marsh
